source: Media playback is not supported on this device World champion Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one and did five pit stops. The Briton faces the prospect of trying to overhaul a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. The incident damaged both cars, with Raikkonen fighting back to fifth behind the Red Bulls of Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo. Raikkonen's rise through the field included passing Hamilton in the closing stages, Ferrari's decision to use soft tyres for the final stint as opposed to the mediums chosen by Mercedes giving the Finn an advantage as the Briton fought in vain to try to pass the Williams of Felipe Massa. Hamilton will express his confidence at being able to erode Rosberg's points lead and will expect his awful luck of the first three races to turnaround - but the fact remains that no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to go on to claim the World Championship. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. By that stage, Hamilton and Raikkonen had already pitted once to replace front wings damaged in first-corner collisions. Raikkonen moved right into Vettel's path as the German moved left to ensure he was not tagged by an aggressive dive down the inside by Kvyat. Hamilton was then turned into by Sauber's Felipe Nasr as he avoided Raikkonen's damaged car swerving back on to the circuit. Vettel confronted Kvyat about the incident in the pre-podium room after the race, saying: "If I don't go left, you crash into us and we all three go out - you are like a torpedo." Kvyat replied: "We didn't crash." Vettel responded: "You didn't. You were lucky this time." Kvyat shrugged: "I'm on the podium; you're on the podium." In the post-race interviews, Kvyat added: "You see the gap, you go for it on the inside. You see one car it is hard to see both. It was a risky move, I agree with Seb but you have to take risks and I am on the podium." Listen to Vettel's post-race rant At the front, Ricciardo had made a stunning start to take the lead from pole-sitter Rosberg at the first corner. In the process his left-rear wheel had been tagged by Rosberg's front wing. Whether it was that or the debris on the track, Ricciardo suffered a left-rear puncture on lap three, allowing the Mercedes to pass. Ricciardo would almost certainly not have been able to hold off Rosberg in any case, but his removal from the lead left the German serene out front. Mercedes decided not to stop him under the safety car and when the race re-started on lap nine, Rosberg simply drove off into the distance. Listen to the first-lap madness Hamilton, meanwhile, was in the wars. Mercedes stopped him twice under the safety car, doing only one lap on the super-soft tyres in an attempt to ensure he could use only the softs for the rest of the race. So Hamilton had done three stops within the first six laps and he was lying third from last at the restart. He began his fightback from there, with the Ferraris doing the same - Vettel starting from 11th and Raikkonen not far behind Hamilton, who said his progress had been affected by damage to the car in the incident with Nasr. "The car was pretty damaged," said the 31-year-old afterwards. "I'm sure it was some aero components but I think it was the suspension as well because it was flexing all over the place." Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said the front wing had damaged the leading edge of the floor and the barge boards when it came off and that the car had lost a "lot of aerodynamic performance". After a further switch to the medium compound tyres to last the race, Hamilton was not able to recover as much ground as the Ferraris and faces an uphill battle if he is to stop Rosberg winning his first world title this year. Chinese Grand Prix race results Chinese Grand Prix coverage details
summary: In the Chinese Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton started from the back due to a grid penalty and suffered a broken front wing on lap one. He did five pit stops and faces a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season. Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, which damaged both cars. Raikkonen recovered to fifth, passing Hamilton in the closing stages. Daniel Ricciardo led from pole but had a puncture on lap three, allowing Nico Rosberg to take the lead and win the race. Hamilton's car was damaged in an incident with Felipe Nasr, affecting his performance. The race was marked by several collisions on the first lap and the introduction of the safety car on lap four. Vettel and Kvyat had a heated exchange in the pre-podium room about an incident involving Kvyat and Vettel.

summary: World champion Hamilton started from the back due to a broken front wing and faced a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season. Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who fought back to fifth. Ferrari's decision to use soft tyres for the final stint gave Raikkonen an advantage over Hamilton. The race was shaped by collisions and the introduction of the safety car on lap four. Hamilton and Raikkonen had already pitted once to replace front wings damaged in first-corner collisions. Hamilton's progress was affected by damage to the car, and he was not able to recover as much ground as the Ferraris. Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said the front wing had damaged the leading edge of the floor and the barge boards. Hamilton faces an uphill battle to stop Rosberg winning his first world title this year.

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the key points from the passage:

1. Nico Rosberg won the Chinese Grand Prix, his third consecutive win of the season.

2. Lewis Hamilton, the world champion, started from the back, suffered a broken front wing, and finished seventh after five pit stops.

3. Sebastian Vettel finished second despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap.

4. The race had an incident-packed opening, leading to a safety car on lap four.

5. Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo of Red Bull finished third and fourth, respectively.

6. There was a post-race confrontation between Vettel and Kvyat about the first-lap incident.

7. Hamilton now faces a 36-point deficit in the championship standings.

8. Hamilton's car suffered significant damage, affecting its aerodynamic performance throughout the race.

9. The passage notes that no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to win the World Championship.

summary: Lewis Hamilton started the race at the back, suffered a broken front wing and did five pit stops. He faces a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races. Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car. Hamilton was turned into by Felipe Nasr as he avoided Raikkonen's damaged car. At the front, Daniel Ricciardo made a stunning start to take the lead from Nico Rosberg at the first corner, but suffered a puncture on lap three, allowing Rosberg to pass. Rosberg drove off into the distance when the race re-started on lap nine. Hamilton was in the wars, stopped twice under the safety car, and was lying third from last at the restart. He began his fightback from there, but was not able to recover as much ground as the Ferraris.

summary: The passage describes a Formula 1 race where Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back due to a broken front wing, faced multiple pit stops and a 36-point deficit in the championship. Sebastian Vettel came in second despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, while Raikkonen fought back to finish fifth. Vettel and Raikkonen used different tyre strategies, which gave Raikkonen an advantage. Hamilton expressed confidence in catching Nico Rosberg, the championship leader, but his early race difficulties made it challenging. The race was marked by several incidents, including collisions on the first lap and aggressive driving tactics.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Lewis Hamilton, the world champion, started from the back of the grid and suffered a broken front wing on the first lap. He made five pit stops and faces a 36-point deficit to leader Nico Rosberg with 18 races remaining. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, while Raikkonen fought back to finish fifth. The incident-packed opening lap led to the introduction of the safety car and several drivers suffered damage, including Hamilton and Raikkonen. Hamilton's progress was hindered by damage to his car and he was unable to recover ground on the Ferraris, leaving him with an uphill battle to stop Rosberg from winning the world title.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

* Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the grid and suffered a broken front wing on lap one, requiring five pit stops throughout the race.
* Hamilton's poor start to the season has left him with a 36-point deficit to teammate Nico Rosberg, who won the Chinese Grand Prix.
* Sebastian Vettel finished second despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, while Raikkonen fought back to finish fifth.
* The incident-packed opening lap led to the introduction of the safety car on lap four, with multiple drivers suffering damage and requiring pit stops.
* Daniel Ricciardo made a strong start to take the lead, but suffered a puncture on lap three and was eventually passed by Rosberg.
* Hamilton faces an uphill battle to overhaul Rosberg's points lead, with no driver having won the first three races of a season and gone on to lose the World Championship.

source: Media playback is not supported on this device World champion Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one and did five pit stops. The Briton faces the prospect of trying to overhaul a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. The incident damaged both cars, with Raikkonen fighting back to fifth behind the Red Bulls of Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo. Raikkonen's rise through the field included passing Hamilton in the closing stages, Ferrari's decision to use soft tyres for the final stint as opposed to the mediums chosen by Mercedes giving the Finn an advantage as the Briton fought in vain to try to pass the Williams of Felipe Massa. Hamilton will express his confidence at being able to erode Rosberg's points lead and will expect his awful luck of the first three races to turnaround - but the fact remains that no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to go on to claim the World Championship. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. By that stage, Hamilton and Raikkonen had already pitted once to replace front wings damaged in first-corner collisions. Raikkonen moved right into Vettel's path as the German moved left to ensure he was not tagged by an aggressive dive down the inside by Kvyat. Hamilton was then turned into by Sauber's Felipe Nasr as he avoided Raikkonen's damaged car swerving back on to the circuit. Vettel confronted Kvyat about the incident in the pre-podium room after the race, saying: "If I don't go left, you crash into us and we all three go out - you are like a torpedo." Kvyat replied: "We didn't crash." Vettel responded: "You didn't. You were lucky this time." Kvyat shrugged: "I'm on the podium; you're on the podium." In the post-race interviews, Kvyat added: "You see the gap, you go for it on the inside. You see one car it is hard to see both. It was a risky move, I agree with Seb but you have to take risks and I am on the podium." Listen to Vettel's post-race rant At the front, Ricciardo had made a stunning start to take the lead from pole-sitter Rosberg at the first corner. In the process his left-rear wheel had been tagged by Rosberg's front wing. Whether it was that or the debris on the track, Ricciardo suffered a left-rear puncture on lap three, allowing the Mercedes to pass. Ricciardo would almost certainly not have been able to hold off Rosberg in any case, but his removal from the lead left the German serene out front. Mercedes decided not to stop him under the safety car and when the race re-started on lap nine, Rosberg simply drove off into the distance. Listen to the first-lap madness Hamilton, meanwhile, was in the wars. Mercedes stopped him twice under the safety car, doing only one lap on the super-soft tyres in an attempt to ensure he could use only the softs for the rest of the race. So Hamilton had done three stops within the first six laps and he was lying third from last at the restart. He began his fightback from there, with the Ferraris doing the same - Vettel starting from 11th and Raikkonen not far behind Hamilton, who said his progress had been affected by damage to the car in the incident with Nasr. "The car was pretty damaged," said the 31-year-old afterwards. "I'm sure it was some aero components but I think it was the suspension as well because it was flexing all over the place." Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said the front wing had damaged the leading edge of the floor and the barge boards when it came off and that the car had lost a "lot of aerodynamic performance". After a further switch to the medium compound tyres to last the race, Hamilton was not able to recover as much ground as the Ferraris and faces an uphill battle if he is to stop Rosberg winning his first world title this year. Chinese Grand Prix race results Chinese Grand Prix coverage details
summary: Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the pack and had a disastrous race, suffering a broken front wing on the first lap and making five pit stops. Despite this, he is confident he can close the 36-point gap to Nico Rosberg in the remaining 18 races. Rosberg won the race after Ricciardo's puncture allowed him to take the lead. Vettel finished second after a collision with Raikkonen on the first lap, and Raikkonen finished fifth after a strong comeback.

summary: The Chinese Grand Prix was a chaotic race, with multiple collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car. Lewis Hamilton started from the back and suffered a broken front wing on lap one, resulting in five pit stops. Despite this, he remains confident in his ability to catch up to Nico Rosberg, who currently holds a 36-point lead in the championship. Sebastian Vettel came second, despite colliding with his teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. Raikkonen fought his way back to fifth place, passing Hamilton in the process. The race was won by Rosberg, who had a comfortable lead after Daniel Ricciardo, who had initially taken the lead, suffered a puncture.

summary: World champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and made five pit stops, leaving him with a 36-point deficit to overcome in the remaining 18 races. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first-lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to finish fifth. The race was marked by a chaotic start, including multiple collisions and a safety car deployment. Daniil Kvyat's aggressive move caused tension with Vettel, who confronted him post-race. Nico Rosberg took the lead after Daniel Ricciardo suffered a puncture and maintained it to win. Hamilton struggled with a damaged car and multiple pit stops, ultimately unable to recover significant ground.
